dictionary.meaning: The New Zealand bellbird. Also known by its other Māori names makomako, and kōmako, is a passerine bird endemic to New Zealand.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Photo of the New Zealand bellbird.

dictionary.meaning: Chatham Island black robin, is an endangered bird from the Chatham Islands off the east coast of New Zealand.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Karure, Kakaruia, Chatham Island black robin bird.

dictionary.meaning: Chatham Island pigeon is a bird endemic to the Chatham Islands in New Zealand & is closely related to the kererū.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Parea, Chatham Island pigeon bird.

dictionary.meaning: The grey warbler is one of the smallest birds found in New Zealand, about 11 centimeters long, with a weight of up to 6.5 grams.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Riroriro, grey warbler bird.

dictionary.meaning: A large parrot belonging to the nestorinae family, a group that includes the kea and the extinct Norfolk Island kākā.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Kākā, a large parrot native to New Zealand that includes Kea.

dictionary.meaning: The kākāpō is the world's only flightless parrot, the world's heaviest parrot, and also is nocturnal, herbivorous, endemic to New Zealand.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Kākāpō, the world's only flightless parrot endemic to New Zealand.

dictionary.meaning: A species of large parrot found in the forested and alpine regions of the South Island of New Zealand. It is one of the most intelligent birds in the world.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Kea bird, a large parrot found in the forested and alpine regions of the South Island of New Zealand.

dictionary.meaning: An endemic New Zealand wattlebirds, an ancient family of birds which includes the North and South Island saddleback and the extinct huia.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Kōkako, an endemic New Zealand wattlebird.

dictionary.meaning: The native morepork is known for its haunting, melancholic call. This sound gives it the Māori name 'ruru'.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Ruru, the native morepork bird known for its haunting, melancholic call.

dictionary.meaning: North Island robin is a friendly and trusting bird and is found in both native and exotic forests. Often come close to people & occasionally stand on a person's boot.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Toutouwai, North Island robin bird.

dictionary.meaning: New Zealand falcon. It is capable of flying at speeds up to 200 km/h and catching prey larger than itself.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Kāreaream, New Zealand falcon bird.

dictionary.meaning: New Zealand parakeet. It means 'small green parrot' in Māori. They are beautiful forest birds. They feed on berries, seeds, fruit and insects, and generally nest in holes in trees.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Kākāriki, New Zealand parakeet bird.

dictionary.meaning: New Zealand pigeon. The kererū is a large bird with irridescent green and bronze feathers on its head and a smart white vest. The noisy beat of its wings is a distinctive sound in our forests.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Kererū, New Zealand pigeon bird.

dictionary.meaning: Rock wren. A small and reclusive bird, rock wrens are restricted to pockets of the South Island’s high country.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Tuke, Pīwauwau, Rock wren bird.

dictionary.meaning: The Saddleback belongs to New Zealand's unique wattlebird family, an ancient group which includes the endangered kōkako and the extinct huia.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Tīeke, Saddleback bird.

dictionary.meaning: Silvereye or wax-eye or sometimes white eye were self introduced to NZ in the 1800s. Their Māori name means 'stranger' or more literally, 'new arrival'.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Tauhou, Silvereye or wax-eye bird.

dictionary.meaning: The stitchbird is a honeyeater-like bird endemic to the North Island and adjacent offshore islands of New Zealand. It's classed as the only member of its own family, the Notiomystidae.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Hihi, Stitchbird bird.

dictionary.meaning: It is a flightless swamphen indigenous to New Zealand and the largest living member of the rail family.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Takahē, a flightless swamphen bird indigenous to New Zealand.

dictionary.meaning: The New Zealand tomtit looks similar to a robin. They are a small bird with a large head, a short bill and tail, and live in forest and scrub. The Māori name of the North Island tomtit is miromiro, while the South Island tomtit is known as ngirungiru.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Miromiro, New Zealand tomtit bird.

dictionary.meaning: A boisterous medium-sized bird native to New Zealand. It is blue, green, and bronze coloured with a distinctive white throat tuft.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Tūī, a boisterous medium-sized bird native to New Zealand.

dictionary.meaning: The Māori name for Wellington Harbour or the great Harbour of Tara.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Aerial photo of Wellington Harbour, New Zealand. By Phillip Capper - Flickr: Wellington Harbour, New Zealand, Nov. 2009, CC BY 2.0

dictionary.meaning: The whitehead is a small species of bird endemic to New Zealand. In many legends, whiteheads were viewed by Māori to have roles as messengers of the gods and as fortune tellers or seers.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Pōpokotea, whitehead bird is a small species of bird endemic to New Zealand.

dictionary.meaning: The yellowhead is a small, insect eating bird which lives only in the forests of New Zealand's South Island and Stewart Island. Since 1991, a yellowhead has appeared on the reverse side of the New Zealand $100 note.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Mohua, yellowhead bird lives in the forests of New Zealand's South Island and Stewart Island.

dictionary.meaning: whale - often used as a general term, particularly for baleen whales.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Southern right whale. By Michaël CATANZARITI - by Michaël CATANZARITI, CC BY-SA 3.0

dictionary.meaning: A large, brown flightless bird that has a famously feisty and curious personality.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Weka, a large, brown flightless bird.

dictionary.meaning: Nelson. A New Zealand city on the eastern shores of Tasman Bay at the top of the South Island.

The Māori name for Auckland, means Tāmaki desired by many. This name refers to the abundance of natural resources, strategic vantage points, portage routes, and mahinga kai which first attracted Māori, and then other settlers.
Geothermal hot pools, boiling spring, volcanic activity, boiling mud pool
To put in place a temporary ritual prohibition, closed season, ban, reserve
Greetings to you (said to one person)
the area for formal discourse in front of a meeting house, or applied to a whole marae complex
The Treaty of Waitangi, sometimes referred to as Te Tiriti, is New Zealand’s founding document. It takes its name from the place in the Bay of Islands where it was first signed, on 6 February 1840.
dictionary.photo_attribution: The Waitangi Sheet of the Treaty of Waitangi. By William Hobson, James Freeman, and James Busby (English version); Henry Williams and Edward Williams (Māori translation)

dictionary.meaning: Lake Tarawera, meaning 'Burnt Spear' is one of the largest lakes in New Zealand. The lake was home to many small Maori villages and mission settlements.
The name Whakaari means 'to make visible' or 'exposed to view'. The full Māori name for the island is te puia whakaari, meaning 'The Dramatic Volcano'.
Hospitality, taking good care of others.
Māori tattooing designs on the face or body.
Used to address a close friend affectionately

(as if saying 'Why kick a moo cow') is a generic name for a small rural town or locality in New Zealand. New Zealanders use the name as a placeholder name for 'any town' or to denote a non-specific but remote rural town. It has a similar connotation to the New Zealand slang Wop Wops.

town located at eastern foot of the Tararua Ranges, has become synonymous with stereotypes of remote rural New Zealand towns, with New Zealanders colloquially referring to the town in the same way other English speakers refer to Timbuktu.

dictionary.word: Hei konā mai me ngā mihi

dictionary.meaning: branch of a river or tree. stream
to land, alight, come to rest, settle on
South Island - an ancient name for Te Wai Pounamu
Land of the Long White Cloud. North Island - now used as the Māori name for New Zealand
Cook Islands - a group of fifteen islands in the SW Pacific
to be handsome, pleasant, beautiful, peaceful, gentle, amiable
to decorate, ornament, beautify, tidy up, adorn
my gain, lucky me, I've got a beauty, I am fortunate
sacred, not to be touched, to be avoided because sacred, taboo
treasured possessions or cultural items, anything precious
Anzac Day - a day (25 April) to commemorate those who have served in the New Zealand and Australian armed forces
to delay, to wait, to hold off to allow maturation of plans etc.
New Zealander of non-Māori descent, usually European
God of the sea and fish
Come; Welcome. Often paired with 'nau mai' to create a more emphatic greeting.

dictionary.photo_attribution: A postcard representing nine stars of Matariki (Māori new year). Disclaimer: AI-generated.

dictionary.meaning: Winter; Second month of the Māori lunar calendar, approximately equivalent to July
One of nine stars of Matariki. Waitī watches over our freshwater environments. Our awa (rivers), roto (lakes), kūkūwai (wetlands), and waipuna (springs)
One of nine stars of Matariki. Waitā surveys our vast oceans, Te Moana-nui-o-Kiwa (the Pacific Ocean) and Te Tai-o-Rehua (the Tasman Sea)
One of nine stars of Matariki. She welcomes the winter sky waters in all their forms – ua (rain) ua nganga (hail) and hukarere (snow) included.

One of nine stars of Matariki. Tupu-ā-nuku has a special interest in our edible plants. This includes the natives pūhā (sowthistle), kawakawa (pepper tree), kōkihi (NZ spinach), and tī kōuka (cabbage tree)
One of nine stars of Matariki. Tupu-ā-rangi has long looked out for the ngahere (forests), and he is deeply concerned by the collapse he is witnessing.

One of nine stars of Matariki. Ururangi is close friends with te whānau puhi (the wind family) – including Hauraro (the north wind), Tonga (the south wind), Hauāuru (the west wind), and Marangai (the east wind)
One of nine stars of Matariki. Pōhutukawa holds tight to our memories of treasured people who have passed on.
One of nine stars of Matariki. Hiwai-i-te-rangi is a wishing star, who helps us to recognise our hopes, dreams and aspirations for the coming year.
Be joyful, euphoric, pleased, glad, cheerful
Snow, foam, froth - also a general term for any of the other white forms of precipitation, i.e hail and frost.
Snow lying on the ground, snow-covered ground
God of the sea and fish
Man. Name given to the Māori and Polynesian god of the forests
Hospitality, taking good care of others.
Māori tattooing designs on the face or body.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Portrait of Tāmati Wāka Nene by Gottfried Lindauer (1890) - Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=22007400

dictionary.meaning: Used to address a close friend affectionately
A Māori proverb that translates to 'Love received demands love returned'
Harbour in the Bay of Plenty; Resting place, anchorage, fishing ground.
The Māori name for Wellington Harbour or the great Harbour of Tara.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Aerial photo of Wellington Harbour, New Zealand. By Phillip Capper - Flickr: Wellington Harbour, New Zealand, Nov. 2009, CC BY 2.0

dictionary.meaning: Mount Maunganui is a 232 metre volcanic dome at the end of a peninsula in the Tauranga.

Wellington. Commonly held to be a phonetic Mori transliteration Port Nicholson. An alternatively suggested etymology for Pneke is that it comes from a shortening of the phrase P Nekeneke, meaning 'journey into the night'
The Māori name for Queenstown. It means 'shallow bay' or 'sandy shore', reflecting the area's original geography.
Connect me to the offerings of my people. https://www.mpp.govt.nz/programmes-and-funding/pacific-languages/pacific-language-weeks/cook-islands-maori-language-week/
dictionary.photo_attribution: Cook Islands Language Week 2025 Poster.
dictionary.word: tui'tuiia au ki te raurau a tku matakeinanga

dictionary.meaning: Container of treasures (Museum of New Zealand)
to land, alight, come to rest, settle on
Place where one has rights of residence and belonging through kinship and whakapapa. A seat or location of identity.
To care for, look after, guard
sacred, not to be touched, to be avoided because sacred, taboo
treasured possessions or cultural items, anything precious
to delay, to wait, to hold off to allow maturation of plans etc.
New Zealander of non-Māori descent, usually European
a term of address for both sexes: E hika
Geothermal hot pools, boiling spring, volcanic activity, boiling mud pool
To put in place a temporary ritual prohibition, closed season, ban, reserve
Greetings to you (said to one person)
the area for formal discourse in front of a meeting house, or applied to a whole marae complex
a term of address for both sexes: E hika
man, husband, god of forests and of birds

dictionary.meaning: to perform traditional dance; haka, a traditional dance, war dance

dictionary.meaning: a female warrior; any strong or brave woman

to repay, respond, avenge. Utu is a 1983 New Zealand war film about the New Zealand Wars. Co-written and directed by Geoff Murphy and depicts the story of a Māori warrior who sets out on a quest for utu (revenge)
dictionary.photo_attribution: Poster of the movie Utu (1983)

dictionary.meaning: The cabbage tree is one of the most distinctive trees in the New Zealand landscape, especially on farms. They grow all over the country, but prefer wet, open areas like swamps.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Picture of a Cabbage tree/tī kōuka Image: Travis Wiens

dictionary.meaning: Chatham Island Christmas tree. The spectacular tree daisy Rautini, sometimes known as the Chatham Island Christmas tree, can grow up to 8 metres tall.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Rautini flowers Photo: John Ragla, CC BY-SA 4.0.

dictionary.meaning: The silver tree fern is a species of medium-sized tree fern, endemic (not found naturally anywhere else) to New Zealand. It arrived relatively late in New Zealand’s history during the Pliocene epoch (around 5 – 1.8 million years ago).
dictionary.photo_attribution: Silver fern. (2024, November 29). In Wikipedia. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver_fern

dictionary.meaning: Golden sand sedge. Pīkao or pīngao, the golden sand sedge (Ficinia), is a native sand-binding sedge that plays an important role in New Zealand's dune ecosystems.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Newly planted pingao Image: Eamonn Ganley

dictionary.meaning: Common flax (harakeke) and mountain flax (wharariki) - There are two identified species of flax in New Zealand.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Common flax/harakeke Image: Jimmy Johnson

dictionary.meaning: Ngutukākā is a plant of special significance to New Zealand. Ngutukākā is named for its beautiful red flowers, which hang in clusters of 15-20 blooms and are shaped liked kaka's a beak. Hence Ngutu meaning beak/lips and Kākā meaning the native parrot of the same name.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Kākābeak Image: Dick Veitch

dictionary.meaning: Kauri are among the world's mightiest trees, growing to over 50 m tall, with trunk girths up to 16 m, and living for over 2,000 years.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Tāne Mahuta, also called 'God of the Forest', is a giant kauri tree (Agathis australis) in the Waipoua Forest of Northland Region, New Zealand. Image: Scott Benjamin

dictionary.meaning: The kōwhai is one of the best known native trees in New Zealand and it’s our unofficial national flower.
dictionary.photo_attribution: Kōwhai flowers Image: Alex Schwab
The reindeer on fresh green pasture. Are G Nilsen, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

dictionary.meaning: reptiles endemic to New Zealand and which, although resembling most lizards, are part of a distinct lineage, the order Rhynchocephalia

dictionary.meaning: to have a holiday, go on holiday
dictionary.photo_attribution: AI-Generated: a retro Volkswagen with a surfboard and bicycles around it. A family on holiday has BBQ while their golden retriever dog is napping.

dictionary.meaning: happy new year, greetings for the new year
dictionary.photo_attribution: Skycity's fireworks display at midnight. Photo/Jason Oxenham
dictionary.word: ngā mihi o te tau hou
